title: 107_hr5278
content: The Act titled "High Productivity and Economic Growth Act of 2002" introduces the High Productivity Investment Deduction under section 168A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The High Productivity Investment Deduction allows taxpayers to treat the cost of high productivity property as an expense, deductible in the year the property is placed in service. High productivity property includes computers, electronic equipment, computer software, and semiconductor manufacturing equipment. The High Productivity Investment Deduction allows taxpayers to expense high productivity property such as computers, electronic equipment, computer software, and semiconductor manufacturing equipment. Additionally, the deduction covers equipment used in the manufacture of semiconductors, high technology medical equipment, advanced technology communications equipment, optical fiber and photonics equipment, advanced environmental products, advanced life science products, and new high productivity assets. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of computer related peripheral equipment and computer based machinery, highlighting their connection to the central processing unit of a computer. The curr_chunk defines electronic diagnostic equipment as devices using electronic components to sense various characteristics, and electronic control equipment as devices that respond to electronically stored information and programmed commands. The curr_chunk defines different types of high technology equipment, including electronic control equipment, high technology medical equipment, and advanced technology communications equipment. The curr_chunk defines optical fiber and photonics equipment as well as advanced environmental and life sciences products. The curr_chunk defines advanced life sciences products as polymers, ceramics, or high-purity glass used in biological research, and new high productivity assets as assets utilizing technological or scientific processes not in common commercial use before January 1, 2001. The Secretary will establish procedures for taxpayers to seek rulings on qualifying assets. The curr_chunk outlines the exclusion criteria for high productivity property, stating that it does not include certain types of vehicles controlled by electronic equipment, entertainment equipment, or office equipment like typewriters and calculators. An election under this section must be made for each taxable year. The election under this section must be made on an asset-by-asset basis on the taxpayer's tax return for the year. Special rules exclude certain property costs and apply antichurning rules to property acquired after September 10, 2002. The taxpayer or a related person can qualify for certain property transactions if the property was owned or used during a specific period, the user of the property remains the same, the property is leased to a person who previously owned or used it, or the property is acquired without a change in user from a related person. The taxpayer or a related person can qualify for certain property transactions based on ownership or usage criteria. Special rules apply, such as property not being considered owned until placed in service, and user changes determined by regulations. Recapture rules may apply for deductions under subsection (a). The taxpayer or a related person can qualify for property transactions based on ownership or usage criteria. Special rules apply, such as property not being considered owned until placed in service, and user changes determined by regulations. Recapture rules may apply for deductions under subsection (a). The election under subsection (a) may not be made with respect to property not predominantly used in a trade or business. Sec. 168A. High productivity investment deduction effective after September 10, 2002. 30 percent expensing for certain property acquired after September 10, 2001, made permanent. Repeal of limitations on acquisition and placed in service rules under section 168(k)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments made to basis limitation for certain property. Syndications rules updated under subparagraph (D) of section 168(k)(2). Amendments are made to the syndications rules under section 168(k)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Property sold within 6 months of being placed in service is treated as originally placed in service on the date of sale. The heading of subsection (k) is amended to remove a specific date reference. Amendments to section 168 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 remove a specific date reference and change effective dates for property placed in service after September 10, 2002. Section 4 states that depreciation rules remain unchanged for the Alternative Minimum Tax purposes. The amendments made by this section exclude property placed in service after September 10, 2002, from depreciation rules for Alternative Minimum Tax purposes. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after September 10, 2002, in taxable years beginning after that date.
